title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
1. Motivating example


Research question: “To what extent do different teaching methods influence students’ ability to produce high-quality written texts?”
Method: Randomization and a CJ experiment. Specifically,




Randomly assign students to two different teaching method
Students will write preferably more than one text
Randomly assign judges to compare random pairs of texts
Judges will produce one dichotomous outcome per comparison
\(\longrightarrow\) reflecting the relative quality of each text






Estimand: “On average, is there a difference in the ability to produce high-quality written texts between two groups of students?”
Estimator: the Bradley-Terry-Luce (BTL) model [1, 2], as it is customary.
Estimates: BTL scores, or their transformations

text:
Issue 1: Case V and statistical analysis
So, are the assumptions of equal dispersion and zero correlation violated?


Thurstone: equal dispersion may not be applicable when researchers assess complex traits or heterogeneous stimuli, like texts!
\(\longrightarrow\) Evidence staring at us in the form of ‘misfit’ statistics?






Equal dispersion:

“misfits” texts are texts with more judgment discrepancies than others [5–8]
“misfit” judges are judges who deviate substantially from the shared consensus.

So, are the assumptions of equal dispersion and zero correlation violated?

Thurstone: equal dispersion may not be applicable when researchers assess complex traits or heterogeneous stimuli, like texts!
\(\longrightarrow\) Evidence staring at us in the form of ‘misfit’ statistics?
Zero correlation is almost certainly invalid in two scenarios:
\(\longrightarrow\) when intricate aspects of texts generate judges’ biases,
\(\longrightarrow\) when there is clustering in the texts


Zero correlation:

additional relevant characteristics, exert an uneven influence on judges’ perceptions, creating biases. Since the discriminal difference of the stimuli becomes an observable outcome only through the judges’ perceptions, these biases introduce dependencies between the stimuli.
the shared context created by additional hierarchical structures introduce dependencies between stimuli (clustering) Not properly handled

Issue 2: Measurement and hypothesis tests
The BTL model serves as the measurement model for CJ [6–8, 11–15]
\(\longrightarrow\) The literature uses point estimates–such as BTL scores or their transformations–to conduct additional analyses, such as:



Identify ‘misfit’ judges and stimuli [6–8]
Detect biases in judges’ ratings [6, 16]
Calculate correlations with other assessment methods [8, 15],
Test hypotheses related to the underlying trait of interest [15, 17–22]




A measurement model specifies how manifest variables contribute to the estimation of latent variables [23]

\(\longrightarrow\) introduce bias + reduce the precision of hypothesis tests [24, 25]

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
4. Extending Thurstone’s general form
So, the outcome’s ability to reflect the “true” differences between texts largely depends on the validity of the model’s assumptions [26].


Thus, we use Causal inference to address these issues and make relevant assumptions.
Particularly, we use SCMs and DAGs [27–30] to formally and graphically represent the assumed causal structure of the CJ system



Benefits:



They can represent causal structures using only five fundamental building blocks [30, 31]
They depict causal relationships in a non-parametric way [28]
They are conceptual models on which identification analysis and consistency rests.





Identification analysis determines whether an estimator can accurately compute an estimand based solely on its (causal) assumptions, regardless of random variability [32]
Consistency refers to the property of an estimator whose estimates converge to the “true” value of the estimand as the data size approaches infinity [23].
Identification is crucial because it is a necessary condition for ensuring consistent estimators. Without identification, consistency cannot be achieved, even with “infinite” and error-free data. Thus, deriving meaningful insights from finite data becomes impossible [32].

section: 5. From SCM to a statistical model
text:
5. From SCM to a statistical model
Finally, with the structure in the previous SCM, we can derive a statistical model that addresses violations of the equal dispersions’ assumption.

Why?



Because SCMs encodes functional and probabilistic information, which we can replace with appropriate functions and probabilistic assumptions [28].
Because SCMs allows us to express the joint distribution of our complex CJ system as a product of simpler conditional probability distributions (CPDs), in the form of:





\[
\begin{aligned}
  P(O_{R}, & S, C, D_{R}, T_{IA}, X_{IA}, e_{IA}, T_{I}, X_{I}, e_{I}, B_{JK}, Z_{JK}, e_{JK}, B_{J}, Z_{J}, e_{J} ) & \\
  &= P(O_{R} \mid D_{R}, S, C) \cdot P(S) \cdot P(C) \cdot P(D_{R} \mid T_{IA}, B_{JK}) \\
  & \quad \cdot P(T_{IA} \mid T_{I}, X_{IA}, e_{IA}) \cdot P(T_{I} \mid X_{I}, e_{I}) \\
  & \quad \cdot P(B_{JK} \mid B_{J}, Z_{JK}, e_{JK}) \cdot P(B_{J} \mid Z_{J}, e_{J}) \\
  & \quad \cdot P(X_{IA}) \cdot P(X_{I}) \cdot P(Z_{JK}) \cdot P(Z_{J}) \\
  & \quad \cdot P(e_{IA}) \cdot P(e_{I}) \cdot P(e_{JK}) \cdot P(e_{J})  
\end{aligned}
\]


This re-expression is possible because the chain rule of probability and the Bayesian Network Factorization (BNF) property. For further details, see [28] and [30].

6. Discussion
Potential benefits of the approach:

It can enhance the reliability and validity of trait measurement [34]
It can improve the accuracy of statistical inferences

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
6. Discussion
Advantages of the model:


It clarifies the interactions among all actors within CJ experiments:




Students and texts
Judges and judgments




It clarifies the processes relevant to CJ experiments, particularly:




The sample mechanism as a generator of missing data. We can now use the missing data mechanisms MCAR, MAR, MNAR [35]
The comparison mechanism as a generator of missing data. We can now use the missing data mechanisms MCAR, MAR, MNAR [35]





Together, advantages 1, 2 and 3 create a principled framework for evaluating best practices in CJ experimental designs–one that aligns better with the demands of contemporary CJ assessment contexts [36].

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
6. Discussion
Advantages of the model:


It shifts the analytic paradigm from passively accepting to actively testing whether the assumptions fit the data [36]. Specifically, we have lifted the necessity of assuming:




Zero correlation between texts
Separate process for trait measurement and hypothesis testing
Equal dispersions between students or texts
No judgment biases
Need for removal of ‘misfit’ observations
Dichotomous outcome
Normal \(e_{IA}, e_{I}, e_{JK},e_{J}\) idiosyncrasies, how about robust models?\(^{1}\)
Only two hierarchical components\(^{1}\)
Multidimensional traits\(^{1}\)





Together, advantages 1, 2 and 3 create a principled framework for evaluating best practices in CJ experimental designs–one that aligns better with the demands of contemporary CJ assessment contexts [36].

Stretching a bit the possibilities. Requires simulation analysis.

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
6.1 Discussion: Future research
Many avenues, but three deserve particular attention:


The impact of sampling and comparison mechanisms
The effects of judges’ bias on the reliability of traits
The identification of ‘misfitting’ judges and stimuli

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
section: 6.2 Discussion: Study limitations and practical challenges for applied CJ researchers
text:
6.2 Discussion: Study limitations and practical challenges for applied CJ researchers


Study limitations:




As with all approaches grounded on causal inference, ours has the limitation of relying on expert knowledge and assumptions about the variables’ causal structure that are often untestable at the outset [37].
However, the theory-driven nature of our approach provides a solid foundation for future empirical evaluation of its causal assumptions [38], which are well supported by both theory and existing evidence.




Practical challenges for applied CJ researchers:




It requires foundational knowledge in causal inference and Bayesian inference methods
It requires more attention for conceptual and statistical modeling. Particularly, ensuring a faithful representation of the CJ system under study and evaluating whether the statistical model can accurately estimate the intended parameters from empirical data.
